text:
I have a strategy that trades in and out of positions.

It can back or lay to enter positions.

After it has backed or layed, it can place an order to exit at my estimate of "fair value".

Without storing any state inside my Python code, is there a way to tag orders, to identify whether or not they are "entry" or "exit trades"?

I'm aware of the "customerStrategyRef" field, and would like that to be the same for both all orders.

The customerOrderRef field is used by Flumine, and uses up all 32 permitted characters.

Is there anything else I could try?

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text:
I have a strategy that trades in and out of positions.

It can back or lay to enter positions.

After it has backed or layed, it can place an order to exit at my estimate of "fair value".

Without storing any state inside my Python code, is there a way to tag orders, to identify whether or not they are "entry" or "exit trades"?

I'm aware of the "customerStrategyRef" field, and would like that to be the same for both all orders.

The customerOrderRef field is used by Flumine, and uses up all 32 permitted characters.

Is there anything else I could try?

text:
Using this code:

```import datetime
import uuid


def from_uuid_time(uuid_time):
    return datetime.datetime(1582, 10, 15) + datetime.timedelta(microseconds=uuid_time//10)


print('Modifying 3rd digit')
d0 = from_uuid_time(13842839081240720)
d1 = from_uuid_time(13942839081240720)
print(d0)
print(d1)
print(d1-d0)```
I get this output:

`1626-08-26 19:18:28.124072`
`1626-12-20 13:05:08.124072`
`115 days, 17:46:40`

So it looks like if I use the 1st two characters of the order id for my own prefix, then I should be safe from clashes for 115 days.:grinning:

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: Using this code:

import datetime
import uuid


def from_uuid_time(uuid_time):
    return datetime.datetime(1582, 10, 15) + datetime.timedelta(microseconds=uuid_time//10)


print('Modifying 3rd digit')
d0 = from_uuid_time(13842839081240720)
d1 = from_uuid_time(13942839081240720)
print(d0)
print(d1)
print(d1-d0)
I get this output:
So it looks like if I use the 1st two characters of the order id for my own prefix, then I should be safe from clashes for 115 days.

text:
Don't seen an issue with doing this but strongly recommend storing state via the LoggingControl and then initialising any orders/trades on startup if required.

Can be as simple as a local json with the current state rather than an API (recommended :slightly_smiling_face: ) or DB

text: <@U01BMTAU1HV> has joined the channel
<@UPMUFSGCR> - Basically the customerOrderRef associated with the bet is designed for this purpose. It is stored in Betfair's data after settling, and accessible with any bets coming through the API

elements.text: - Basically the customerOrderRef associated with the bet is designed for this purpose. It is stored in Betfair's data after settling, and accessible with any bets coming through the API

text: It is the ONLY guaranteed way to match a bet you place and the bet updates coming through the streaming API, and doesn't rely on any state management in your own software (as long as you store the bet requests, or give that field enough information to uniquely identify any bet)

elements.text: It is the ONLY guaranteed way to match a bet you place and the bet updates coming through the streaming API, and doesn't rely on any state management in your own software (as long as you store the bet requests, or give that field enough information to uniquely identify any bet)
